questions.question_text: What does the current European Telecommunications Standards Institute rule state is the 2.4-GHz maximum transmitter output power for point-to-point installations?

questions.answer_description:
The icon with the top half yellow and the lower half red indicates that the optional 802.11a Cisco Radio (top) has a minor fault, and the 802.11b/g Cisco Radio
(bottom) has a major or critical fault. The worst of the two Cisco Radio colors determines the color of the large triangular pointer. http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/wcs/7-0MR1/configuration/guide/WCS70MR1/maps.html#wp1090761

choices.E: The 802.11b/g/n radio has a minor fault.
choices.C: The 802.11a/n radio has a major fault.
choices.B: The 802.11a/n radio has a minor fault.
choices.F: The 802.11b/g/n radio has a major fault.

discussion.content: Actually I was wrong on the below comment. Per the link, the answer is correct.
2.4 is on top. So the 2.4 has a minor fault and the 5 ghz has a major fault.

This question belongs to the former exam 640-722, the WCS is obsolote and not in use any more on the latest Wireless versions replaced by WLC and Cisco Prime. Therefore, I would not take care too much about this question.

comments.content:
I cannot figure out why D is correct.
There doesn't seem to be anything in the images pertaining to MSE.

discussion.content: B is correct because Cisco 1260 APs do not support Cleanair.

questions.answer_description:
The set-up formed by the access point and the stations located within its coverage area are called the basic service set (or infrastructure basic service set, or BSS for short). Each BSS forms one cell.
We can link several BSS's together (it means we link access points) using a connection called a distribution system in order to form an extended service set or
ESS. The distribution system can also be a wired network, a cable between two access points or even a wireless network.
Note: When a station moves from one access point to another in an ESS, it is called roaming.
questions.question_text: Which statement about an infrastructure basic service set is true according to IEEE 802.11 specifications?

discussion.content: Be careful not to mix up IBSS (independent basic service set) and infrastructure basic service set. IBSS is an ad-hoc network

choices.A: The set also is called an ad hoc network.
choices.B: The BSSID is generated from the first wireless client that starts up in the IBSS.
choices.C: The set enables the use of ESS.
choices.D: No signals are relayed from one client to another client.

questions.answer_description:
Enter your username in the User Name field. The default username is Cisco. Enter the wireless device password in the Password field and press Enter. The default password is Cisco. The Summary Status page appears.
The access point is configured with the factory default values including the IP address (set to receive an IP address using DHCP). To obtain the new IP address for an access point/bridge, you can use the show interface bvi1 CLI command. http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/access_point/12-4-25d-JA/Configuration/guide/cg_12_4_25d_JA/scg12-4-25d-JA-chap4-first.html

discussion.content:
The correct answer is CE.

Frome Official Cert Guide page 217
By default, you can leave the username blank and enter the password as Cisco.
xtrattitude4u is right in principle, but there is no correct answer here. Username and password in answer A is "cisco" (with small "c"), which is not correct.

The Correct answer is AE according to the documentation.
You need to login with a default username of "Cisco" and password of "Cisco"
